chapter: Androgens and Drugs for Erectile Dysfunction

questions.question: Which of the following is the most potent androgen?
questions.chapter_heading: Androgens and Drugs for Erectile Dysfunction

questions.question: Aromatase converts testosterone into
questions.explanation: Aromatase (CYP19) converts testosterone to estradiol. Certain effects of testosterone are mediatedby estradiol.In men with deficient CYP19 or ER receptors, the epiphyses do not fuse, the long bones growindefinitely and such patients are osteoporotic. Administration of estradiol can correct the boneabnormalities in CYP19 deficiency. However, this cannot be used in those with ER receptordefects.Testosterone is converted to dihydrotestosterone (DHT) by 5-alpha-reductase.Androstanedione and epiandrosterone are metabolites of DHT due to the action of 17-beta-HSD.
questions.chapter_heading: Androgens and Drugs for Erectile Dysfunction

questions.question: A 59-year-old man with metastatic prostate cancer is started on flutamide therapy. What isthe mechanism of action of this drug?
questions.explanation: Flutamide acts by competitive inhibition of androgen receptors and is used to treat prostatecancer.Flutamide is a non-steroidal antiandrogen that competes with androgens such as testosterone anddihydrotestosterone for binding to the androgen receptors in the prostate gland. By doing so, itprevents them from stimulating the prostate cancer cells to grow.In addition to its use in prostate cancer, flutamide has been used to treat hyperandrogenism(excess androgen levels) in women, such as in those with polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS) and691Hirsutism.Other anti-androgens are:• Bicalutamide, apalutamide, and nilutamide•• Spironolactone (aldosterone antagonist with antiandrogen activity)•Cyproterone acetate (progestin with antiandrogen activity)• Cimetidine (H2 blocker with anti-androgen activity)Selective Androgen Receptor Modulators (SARMs) are a class of androgen receptor ligands thathave similar anabolic properties to anabolic steroids, but with reduced androgenic side effects.There are no FDA-approved SARMs at present.
questions.chapter_heading: Androgens and Drugs for Erectile Dysfunction

questions.question: A 25-year-old medical student is worried about his receding hairline and is thinking abouttaking finasteride. The drug enhances hair growth by acting on which of the following?
questions.explanation: Finasteride is a competitive inhibitor of 5 ° -reductase enzyme and thereby inhibits the conversionof testosterone to dihydrotestosterone.•Finasteride selectively inhibits the Type 2 isoenzyme of 5° -reductase. It is indicated for use in:Benign prostatic hyperplasia• Male pattern baldness• Hirsutism.
questions.chapter_heading: Androgens and Drugs for Erectile Dysfunction

questions.question: Which of the following inhibits spermatogenesis?
questions.explanation: Gossypol is a non-steroidal agent that inhibits spermatogenesis.Gossypol is obtained from cottonseed. It inhibits spermatogenesis by exerting toxic effects onseminiferous tubules but has low efficacy. Libido and potency are not significantly affected andfertility usually returns after a few months of discontinuation of the drug. But, around 10% of thepatients may remain infertile. Hypokalemia is a major adverse effect and may even lead totransient paralysis.Low efficacy and significant toxicity have caused gossypol to be abandoned as a candidate malecontraceptive.
questions.chapter_heading: Androgens and Drugs for Erectile Dysfunction

questions.question: A 30-year-old male patient presented to the urology OPD with complaints of erectiledysfunction and was prescribed a PDE-5 inhibitor. Identify the drug.
questions.explanation: Tadalafil is a PDE-5 inhibitor used in the treatment of patients with erectile dysfunction.Penile erection is mediated by NO and cGMP. During arousal, the corpus cavernosum producesnitric oxide which in turn stimulates the formation of cGMP. This leads to relaxation of thesmooth muscle of corpus cavernosum and penile arteries, causing engorgement of corpuscavernosum producing an erection. The biological actions of cGMP are terminated by692phosphodiesterase enzymes and PDE-5 is the major cGMP metabolizing enzyme in the peniletissue.Phosphodiesterase-5-inhibitors include:• Sildenafil• Tadalafil - Longest acting (24-36 hrs), bioavailability is not affected by food• Vardenafil.• Avanafil - Most Rapid-acting (within 15 -30 mins)Option A: Podofilox topical cream is used in the treatment of genital warts and molluscumcontagiosum lesions.Option B: Finasteride is a 5 ° -reductase inhibitor.Option C: Apalutamide is a androgen receptor antagonist.
questions.chapter_heading: Androgens and Drugs for Erectile Dysfunction

questions.question: A 40-year-old diabetic patient was prescribed sildenafil for his erectile dysfunction. Followingthis, he develops a blurring of vision and complains that things seem to appear with abluish-green hue. Inhibition of which of the following enzymes is likely to have caused hisvisual side effects?Phosphodiesterase 3b) Phosphodiesterase 5c) Phosphodiesterase 6d) Phosphodiesterase 2Question 8:689Which of the following is a prostaglandin that can be administered as an intracavernosalinjection for erectile dysfunction?
questions.explanation: Visual disturbance seen with sildenafil is due to PDE-6 inhibition.Sildenafil is used for the treatment of erectile dysfunction principally due to its inhibitory actionson PDE-5 (Phosphodiesterase 5) in the vascular tissues of the corpus cavernosa. However, it alsoexerts minor inhibitory action against PDE-6, which is present exclusively in rod and conephotoreceptors and results in blurring and blue-green tinting of vision.Tadalafil and avanafil have better PDE-5/PDE-6 selectivity, compared to sildenafil and vardenafiland hence have lesser visual side effects.
questions.chapter_heading: Androgens and Drugs for Erectile Dysfunction

questions.question: A 35-year-old physician presented to the ED with a prolonged painful erection induced byintracorporeal injection of an alprostadil+phentolamine combination. He had been using thistechnique to overcome occasional performance anxiety. Corporeal aspiration reveals darkcoloured blood and based on further workup, a diagnosis of low flow priapism is made.Which of the following is the drug of choice to treat his condition?
questions.explanation: Phenylephrine is the drug of choice for the treatment of low flow priapism.Characteristics of low-flow priapism include painful rigid erection and ischemic corpora, indicatedby dark blood upon corporeal aspiration.Prazosin, and, phenoxybenzamine are alpha-blockers that cause vasodilation and can worsenpriapism.693
questions.chapter_heading: Androgens and Drugs for Erectile Dysfunction

questions.question: A 19-year-old male athlete seeks your opinion on the usage of anabolic steroids to improve hisperformance. What would be your advice?

options.A: Reassure the patient that all anabolic steroids are safe to use
options.B: Explain clearly that only newer anabolic steroids are safe to use as they have negligibleandrogenic action
options.C: Advice against use and sensitise the patient that all anabolic steroids have significantandrogenic action
options.D: Explain that older testosterone preparations are more appropriate for use in male athletes

questions.explanation: All anabolic steroids have significant androgenic action and the use of anabolic steroids byathletes is not recommended.Testosterone and its derivatives are used for their anabolic effects but they have significantandrogenic action. Some of them (17 methyl derivatives) are also hepatotoxic. The currentconsensus is to advise against the use of such anabolic steroids.694
questions.chapter_heading: Androgens and Drugs for Erectile Dysfunction
